data.title: Communications Services Up Amid Deal Speculation -- Communications Services Roundup
data.description:
Communications-services companies rose amid deal speculation.

Warner Bros Discovery rose after Reuters reported that Netflix was weighing a bid for the studio's streaming services, following repeated efforts by Paramount Skydance to buy its rival.

Charter Communications reported lower third-quarter profit as increased competition from fixed wireless and fiber connection hurts its broadband internet business.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 1812ET

data.title: Tech Up After Amazon, Apple Earnings -- Tech Roundup
data.description:
Shares of technology companies rose after earnings from Amazon.com and Apple eased fears about an artificial-intelligence bubble.

Amazon.com ended a volatile week for the sector on a winning note as its shares surged by more than 10% following a blockbuster quarter for its cloud-computing unit, which supports AI software. "We continue to see strong demand in AI and core infrastructure, and we've been focused on accelerating capacity," Amazon Chief Executive Andy Jassy said in a statement.

Apple shares rose after the gadget maker forecast strong holiday-season sales of its latest iPhone 17 model, and vowed to boost its spending on AI infrastructure to catch up on peers.

On a technical basis, the stock market is exhibiting some signs of a bubble about to pop, said one strategist. The stock market is unusually "bifurcated" with a relatively high percentage of both new 52-week highs and 52-week lows, said Lorenzo Di Mattia, manager of hedge fund Sibilla Global Fund. This pattern, sometimes called the "Hindenburg omen" has "historically resolved with broad weakness," said Di Mattia.

U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods are still historically high, even after Trump lowered them somewhat, and strategists expect tensions to rise again, particularly on sensitive technology that both nations view as part of their struggle for world leadership.

Shares of Western Digital rose after the data-storage company reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings and new orders from "hyperscaler" customers.

Security and network specialist F5 posted fourth-quarter profit growth, boosted by demand from artificial-intelligence companies.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 1810ET

data.title: Mercedes-Benz Group says buyback program valued up to EUR 2 billion
Financials Up Amid Earnings Optimism -- Financials Roundup
data.description:
Shares of banks and other financial institutions rose slightly amid earnings optimism.

Shares of brokerage LPL Financial rose after it reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings, buoyed by its recent acquisition of rival Commonwealth Financial Network.

Online brokerage Robinhood rallied ahead of its earnings report next week.

One strategist said the private-credit worries that tanked regional bank shares recently could resurface. "Private credit is drawing fresh scrutiny," said Lorenzo Di Mattia, manager of hedge fund Sibilla Global Fund. Scares from bankruptcies and JPMorgan Chase Chief Executive Jamie Dimon's warning of contagion "haven't yet produced major follow-through, but regional bank jitters could re-emerge if stress builds," said Di Mattia.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 1801ET

data.title: Consumer Cos Rally After Amazon Earnings -- Consumer Roundup
data.description:
Consumer companies rallied as strong earnings from Amazon.com offset warnings from consumer-staple firms.

Newell Brands plunged after the maker of Sharpies and other consumer staples warned that price hikes drew resistance from consumers in the third quarter, pushing sales lower and causing the company to cut its full-year outlook.

Toiletry giant Colgate-Palmolive said inflation, trade uncertainty and consumer wariness continued to weigh on sales and profit across the consumer-goods sector.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 1757ET

data.title: Vestand Inc co's unaudited consolidated financial statements for three and six months ended June 30, 2025, and 2024 unreliable - SEC filing
Health Care Up Amid Earnings Optimism -- Health Care Roundup
data.description:
Health-care companies rose amid earnings optimism.

Eli Lilly added to gains, amid a sense that the maker of Mounjaro and Zepbound is pulling away from its competition in the obesity-drug boom.

Shares of Novo Nordisk, the Danish maker of Ozempic and Wegovy, which had long led the weight-control drug sales, fell after analysts at brokerage Deutsche Bank said a $9 billion attempt to wrest Metsera from the arms of its merger partner Pfizer looked like a "defensive" rather than expansionary move.

AbbVie raised its full-year adjusted earnings outlook, even though profit was pressured by increased expenses during the third quarter.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 1754ET

Dynamix Corporation iii completes $201.25 million initial public offering
Brazil's Petrobras to hike average jet fuel prices by 1.4% as of November
Adicet Bio reports inducement grants under Nasdaq listing rule 5635(c)(4)
Industrials Up, Paring Losses for Week -- Industrials Roundup
data.description:
Shares of industrial and transportation companies ticked up, paring losses for the week, amid mixed earnings and a mixed reception for a trade truce.

Canadian National Railway reported a rise in third-quarter profit and revenue due to higher freight volumes transported.

Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney accepted an invitation to China from President Xi Jinping, in a sign that trade tensions with the U.S. have pushed the two nations closer.

Elon Musk's SpaceX is set to receive $2 billion to develop satellites that can track missiles and aircraft under President Trump's Golden Dome project.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 1751ET

data.title: Materials Down as Precious-Metals Rally Stalls -- Materials Roundup
data.description:
Producers of metals and other raw materials fell as a precious-metals rally stalled.

Gold futures fell 0.5% for the session to drop below the psychologically significant $4,000 an ounce level, but gained 3.7% for the month amid a historic rally in precious metals.

Miners such as Newmont and Barrick Gold fell in sympathy.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 1748ET

data.title: Energy Up Amid Strong Earnings -- Energy Roundup
data.description:
Shares of energy companies rose amid generally strong earnings.

Exxon Mobil shares rose slightly after the largest U.S. oil producer by revenue said increased production at two major oilfields offset lower oil prices.

Chevron rose after the second largest U.S. oil producer weathered the drop in oil prices better than analysts had anticipated.

U.S. natural gas futures rose for a third straight session to end the week and month higher.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-31-25 1747ET

Investing Heavily in AI as Models Improve: GoDaddy CEO
data.description:
Aman Bhutani, GoDaddy (GDDY) CEO, says the company's AI transformation is focused on generative AI tools. He tells Katie Greifeld and David Gura on "The Close" that by the end of this year, GoDaddy aims for 70% of its code to be AI-generated.

Amgen Announces Dividend for Fourth Quarter of 2025, Payable on December 12, 2025
data.description: Amgen announced that its Board of Directors declared a $2.38 per share dividend for the fourth quarter of 2025. The dividend will be paid on December 12, 2025, to all stockholders of record as of the close of business on November 21, 2025.

data.title: US to announce that Nexperia's Chinese facilities will resume shipments, source says
DTE Energy to Supply Energy for Oracle's Upcoming Michigan Data Center
data.description:
By Dean Seal


DTE Energy on Friday detailed its agreement to provide energy for Oracle's multibillion-dollar data center campus coming to southeast Michigan.

The Detroit utility said Friday that its board has approved primary supply and energy storage agreements with an Oracle subsidiary, under which it will provide about 1.4 gigawatts of electric service to the future facility.

The supply deal runs through February 2024, with options for an extension. Electric service will ramp over time and reach full delivery in December 2027.

As part of the storage agreement, DTE will build storage capacity for the 1.4 gigawatts and operate the storage facility for at least 15 years.

Developer Related Cos. struck a deal with DTE and Oracle to build a more than $7 billion data-center campus on farmland outside Detroit, according to a report from the Wall Street Journal. Technology giants are in a race to secure massive amounts of power needed for their data center projects, giving utility companies a major role in the artificial intelligence boom.


Write to Dean Seal at dean.seal@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires
